Historical Background



Moses Plan

In response to the Planning Commission’s recommendation of Route
A, the Mayor appointed a special traffic committee, headed by Mr. E.
Asbury Davis, to study the matter. This in turn led to the employment
by the City of Mr. Robert Moses and a group of special consultants
associated with Mr. Moses in his various New York activities. The Moses
group prepared a report, dated October, 1944, recommending the con-
struction of an expressway through the center of the City. The Moses
Plan is simple to describe. It was virtually identical to Route A.

Smith Plan

The background of the Smith Plan is somewhat involved. In January
of 1943 Mayor Jackson, anticipating the need for large expenditures for
highways in the post-war period, initiated action to secure approval of a
bond issue for this purpose. As a result the General Assembly, early in
1944, authorized the issuance of a $20,000,000 bond issue for major
highway purposes. The specific projects to be covered were not spelled
out but it was generally held that a cross-town expressway would be the
most important project involved. Ten Million Dollars of this authoriza-
tion was placed on the ballot in the fall of 1944 and approved by the
voters. More or less concurrently the Federal Highway Act of 1944 was
adopted. This Act made Federal funds available on a matching basis
which could have been used for the cross-town expressway. A request by
the City to the State to appropriate the necessary matching funds was
rejected by the General Assembly early in 1945. It would appear that the
publicity attending the issuance of the Moses Report in October of 1944
crystallized objections to this route on the part of affected property
owners and that this opposition was reflected in the General Assembly’s
disapproval. It was also believed, however, that the absence of an
accepted comprehensive plan for major highways within the City was a
factor in .the General Assembly’s disapproval and accordingly Mayor

McKeldin requested Mr. Nathan L. Smith, then the City’s Chief Engi-
neer, to prepare a complete report on this subject.

Mr. Smith’s report, released in May, 1945, has historic interest pri-
marily because it represents the first effort to develop an expressway
pattern for the City. (See Sheet 3). It is also the first plan based upon
an inner ring around the central business district. The east side of this
inner ring consists of an elevated expressway along the Fallsway which,
north of the Pennsylvania Railroad, runs along Barclay Street and then
turns towards the northeast along Loch Raven Road. This proposal was
adapted from a recommendation of the Advisory Engineers.

The main cross-town route in the Smith Plan substantially follows
Route B from the eastern City line to the Fallsway, jogs south on the
elevated structure, runs west along Route A to the Mulberry-Franklin-
Pine-Myrtle block (thus forming the northern segment of the inner
ring), continues due south to Pratt Street (forming the western side of
the inner ring), and continues generally southerly along Russell Street.
The route was designed to tie in with the new Washington-Baltimore
Expressway, then in a planning stage.

The south side of the inner ring consists of an elevated expressway
along Pratt Street.

A year after the Smith report the City Council authorized the ex-
penditure of $350,000 for preliminary plans for an expressway through
the City following the Smith route. Despite this approval, several subse-
quent attempts to obtain authorization for the preparation of final plans
for the first sections of this route in the southwest part of the City (so as
to receive the new Washington-Baltimore Expressway) were rejected by
the Council. It was not until the City administration in 1949 gave assur-
ances that it would make no further attempt to push the entire Smith
route that the Council relented and granted the approval that led to the

s
